Hi! I'm trying to learn Lean and I thought this project looked interesting.

I was trying to prove 0-over-lim: Limit-preserving functors lift to over categories, and I think it's false as stated.

It says the following: let JJJ be a category. If a functor preserves limits of shape JJJ, then the induced functor in the over categories preserves limits of shape JJJ as well.

The problem is that the shape of the limits has to change once you pass to the over category. Take, for example, J={A,B}J = \{A, B\}J={A,B} to be two objects and no non-trivial morphisms. Then, a functor J→C J \to C J→C is a choice of two objects in CCC, and the limit of such a functor is the product of two objects. On the other side, a functor from J→C/XJ \to C/XJ→C/X is a diagram with three objects, and the limit of such a functor is a fibered product over XXX.

There are functors which preserve products, but not finite products. For example (****wrong example, sorry), in the category of abelian groups, the functor M↦Hom⁡(Z/2Z,M)M\mapsto \operatorname{Hom}({\mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z}, M)M↦Hom(Z/2Z,M) preserves products (direct sums), but it does not preserve the fibered product Z×Z/2Z\mathbb Z \times_{\mathbb Z/2} \mathbb ZZ×Z/2​Z.

This also works as an example that PreservesFiniteProducts.overPost in CategoryTheory/Limits/Preserves/Finite.lean is false.

I haven't yet figured out what this is used for. Anyway, I would love to attempt to contribute, but my knowledge of Lean is tiny.

I am a bit confused by what you're saying. The claim is that if some functor preserves limits of shape J then some other functor does too. What is your functor and what is J in your proposed counterexample?

Sorry, let me clarify all the notation. The theorem says that CCC is a category, XXX is an object, F ⁣:C→DF\colon C\to DF:C→D preserves limits of shape JJJ. Then, F ⁣:C/X→D/F(X)F\colon C/X\to D/F(X)F:C/X→D/F(X) preserves limits of shape JJJ. I'm claiming that in the conclusion, the shape should be different. In my example:

  • C=D=AbC=D=\mathbf {Ab}C=D=Ab
  • X=Z/2ZX = \mathbb Z/2\ZX=Z/2Z
  • F(M)=M/2MF (M) = M/2MF(M)=M/2M

  • JJJ is a category with two objects and no morphisms between them.

  • A functor c ⁣:J→Cc\colon J\to Cc:J→C is the same as a choice of two objects in CCC. The limit of this functor, if it exists, is the product of these objects.

  • A functor c ⁣:J→C/Xc\colon J\to C/Xc:J→C/X is the same as a choice of two objects with morphisms A→XA\to XA→X and B→XB\to XB→X. The limit is the fibered product A×XBA\times_X BA×X​B.

I am doubtful that we actually need this because the functor we care about is a right adjoint and this follows from the "adunction in over category" thing. But this would be a great addition into mathlib anyways.

The thing we want in mathlib might be:

  1. If J is connected and F preserves it, then so does Over.post F.
  2. If F preserves products indexed by I, then Over.post F preserves pullbacks indexed by I.
It would also be nice to have the colimit version. Here I think the (analogous to original) claim is true.
